app.title: How the Brain Shapes Behavior
app.description: Learn to recognize which brain system is active in different life situations.

landing.title: How the Brain Shapes Behavior
landing.subtitle: Learn to recognize which brain system is active in different life situations.
landing.description: The brain has three main systems — each handles its own tasks. Take this short quiz to discover what these systems are and when each one is in charge.

stage2Intro.question: Now for a harder task. Can you tell which part of the brain is in charge and which one is being controlled?

screen1.title: The Triune Brain
screen1.body: Paul MacLean, a prominent neuroscientist, proposed describing the brain with a model of three parts. It is a simplification, but it helps us understand how and why we react to the world.

screen2.title: The Reptilian Brain
screen2.body: The oldest part of the brain, present in reptiles. The reptilian brain handles automatic reactions. When it is hot — the body sweats; when it is cold — it shivers.

screen3.title: The Limbic System
screen3.body: Evolved in mammals. It is the center of emotions. Fear, anger, joy, excitement. The limbic system is responsible for all of this.

screen4.title: The Neocortex
screen4.body: The newest addition, unique to higher primates. It handles perception of the world, memory, and thinking. It's what allows us to solve equations, write poetry, and fill out tax returns.

screen5.title: Ready to Test Yourself?
screen5.body: Can you recognize which part of the brain is involved in a given situation?

quiz.questionMain: Which part of the brain is responsible for this?
quiz.questionQ1: Who is in charge and sending the signal?

main1.title: Hot Surface
main1.description: The hand pulls away from a hot surface before the mind even registers that it's hot.
main1.why: The reptilian brain carries out reflex actions to protect the body.

main2.title: Social Approval
main2.description: After praise from colleagues, a wave of warmth spreads and a slight smile appears, even when trying to stay neutral.
main2.why: The limbic system is involved in the emotional response to social reward.

main3.title: Tax Return
main3.description: Filling out a tax return and carefully checking the numbers.
main3.why: The neocortex handles logic, numbers, and planning.

main4.title: Car Stops Ahead
main4.description: When the car ahead stops suddenly, the brake is pressed automatically.
main4.why: The reptilian brain triggers fast, automatic reactions to avoid danger.

main5.title: Nervous Before a Presentation
main5.description: Before an important presentation, a feeling of nervousness arises.
main5.why: The limbic system processes emotions of anxiety and anticipation.

main6.title: Planning a Trip
main6.description: Planning a trip—connections, layovers, and travel time all factored in.
main6.why: The neocortex handles planning and abstract thinking.

main7.title: Something Flew Past the Face
main7.description: When something moves sharply past the face, the eyes blink automatically.
main7.why: The reptilian brain triggers protective reflexes faster than conscious processing.

main8.title: Awkward After a Joke
main8.description: After a joke that falls flat, a feeling of awkwardness arises.
main8.why: The limbic system processes social emotions, including embarrassment.

main9.title: Comparing Job Offers
main9.description: Comparing two job offers and choosing the better one.
main9.why: The neocortex handles analysis and decision-making.

main10.title: Footsteps Behind at Night
main10.description: At the sound of footsteps behind at night, the body turns around sharply.
main10.why: The reptilian brain triggers the response to a perceived threat.

main11.title: Jealousy
main11.description: At the sight of a partner with someone else, a feeling of jealousy arises.
main11.why: The limbic system processes emotions of attachment and jealousy.

main12.title: Saving for a Purchase
main12.description: Working out how many months it would take to save up for a purchase.
main12.why: The neocortex handles logical calculation and planning.

main13.title: Stepping on Something Sharp
main13.description: When stepping on something sharp, the foot jerks back automatically.
main13.why: The reptilian brain provides protective reflexes.

main14.title: Smiling When Meeting Someone
main14.description: Meeting someone close—a spontaneous smile appears.
main14.why: The limbic system is involved in emotional responses of attachment.

main15.title: Reading a Complex Contract
main15.description: Reading and analyzing a complex contract carefully.
main15.why: The neocortex handles language, logic, and abstract thinking.

main16.title: Door Slam
main16.description: An unexpected door slam—the body flinches before there's time to think.
main16.why: The reptilian brain reacts to sudden stimuli with a protective reflex.

main17.title: Shame About the Past
main17.description: When remembering a situation from the past, a feeling of shame arises.
main17.why: The limbic system links memory to emotional experience.

main18.title: Investment Analysis
main18.description: Studying an investment chart before making a decision.
main18.why: The neocortex handles rational analysis and forecasting.

main19.title: Losing Balance
main19.description: When slipping, the body automatically restores balance.
main19.why: The reptilian brain coordinates automatic movement and balance reactions.

main20.title: Worry About Others' Opinion
main20.description: Anxiety arises about possible judgment from others.
main20.why: The limbic system processes social anxiety and worry.

what1.title: Solving a Puzzle
what1.description: Working through a logic puzzle step by step.
what1.why: The neocortex handles reasoning and step-by-step analysis.

what2.title: Reflex to a Loud Bang
what2.description: A loud bang nearby—the body jumps before there's time to think.
what2.why: The reptilian brain triggers an immediate startle response to sudden threat.

what3.title: Feeling Moved by a Song
what3.description: A song brings back a memory and an emotional response is felt.
what3.why: The limbic system links memory and emotion.

what4.title: Unexpected Touch
what4.description: Someone touches a shoulder from behind and a reaction happens before turning.
what4.why: One of the three brain systems is primarily responsible for this response.

what5.title: Choosing What to Eat
what5.description: Standing in front of the fridge, trying to decide what to eat.
what5.why: One of the three brain systems is primarily responsible for this response.

what6.title: Reacting to a Compliment
what6.description: After praise for their work, a rush of warmth and a slight smile appear.
what6.why: One of the three brain systems is primarily responsible for this response.

ctrl1.title: Footsteps at Night
ctrl1.description: Walking down an empty street at night when fast footsteps sound behind. The body tenses, the heart speeds up. A few seconds later the situation is reassessed—just a passerby—and tension gradually eases.
ctrl1.why: The neocortex reassessed the situation and dampened the limbic response.

ctrl2.title: Before a Presentation
ctrl2.description: Before an important presentation, the pulse quickens and the palms sweat. Breathing is consciously slowed and attention is focused on its rhythm. Gradually the body calms down.
ctrl2.why: The neocortex, through conscious regulation, influenced the reptilian stress response.

ctrl3.title: Aggressive Comment
ctrl3.description: After reading an aggressive comment, an impulse to reply sharply arises. Instead, the tab is closed and the response is postponed.
ctrl3.why: The neocortex suppressed the limbic impulse to react immediately.

ctrl4.title: Branch Cracks in the Forest
ctrl4.description: A sharp crack is heard nearby in the forest. An instant freeze happens. Then anxious anticipation of possible danger arises.
ctrl4.why: The reptilian brain triggered the freeze response; then the limbic system added the emotional assessment.

ctrl5.title: Anger During an Argument
ctrl5.description: During an argument, strong anger arises. At some point it becomes hard to take in the other person's arguments and to form thoughts clearly.
ctrl5.why: The limbic system overloaded the neocortex's ability for rational analysis.

ctrl6.title: Before a Blood Test
ctrl6.description: Before a medical procedure, anxiety kicks in and breathing becomes uneven. Then the thought comes that it's a safe procedure, and the body gradually calms.
ctrl6.why: The neocortex, through rational explanation, dampened the limbic response.

ctrl7.title: Car Horn
ctrl7.description: At a sharp car horn, the body flinches. Then irritation and a mental reaction to the situation appear.
ctrl7.why: The reptilian brain caused the initial response; then the limbic system added the emotional assessment.

ctrl8.title: Fear of Flying
ctrl8.description: Fear of flying arises. Then flight safety statistics are looked up to reduce the anxiety.
ctrl8.why: The neocortex used facts to influence the limbic fear response.

ctrl9.title: Nervous Before a Meeting
ctrl9.description: Before a meeting, strong nervousness arises. Tension in the body and discomfort in the stomach appear.
ctrl9.why: The limbic system set the emotional state and influenced the bodily response.

ctrl10.title: Strange Sound at Night
ctrl10.description: At night a strange sound is heard. The body is already tense. A few seconds later a logical analysis of possible causes begins.
ctrl10.why: The reptilian brain reacted first; then control passed to the neocortex.

ctrl11.title: Hurtful Words in a Conversation
ctrl11.description: In a conversation, hurtful words are said. Resentment arises; speech becomes faster and less restrained.
ctrl11.why: The limbic system weakened the neocortex's control over speech.

ctrl12.title: Shallow Breathing from Stress
ctrl12.description: Under stress, breathing becomes shallow. Then breathing is consciously evened out and muscles are relaxed.
ctrl12.why: The neocortex, through conscious regulation, influenced the reptilian response.

ctrl13.title: Edge of a Cliff
ctrl13.description: Walking along the edge of a cliff, the pace slows automatically. Then a feeling of anxiety appears.
ctrl13.why: The reptilian brain triggered caution; then the limbic system added the emotional assessment.

ctrl14.title: Strong Emotions After News
ctrl14.description: After important news, intense emotions take over. Then thoughts are written down to sort through the feelings.
ctrl14.why: The neocortex helped organize the limbic emotional state.

ctrl15.title: During a Conflict
ctrl15.description: During a conflict, the heart beats faster and the face flushes. The ability to reason calmly drops.
ctrl15.why: The limbic system dominated and weakened the neocortex's cognitive control.

ctrl16.title: Before an Exam
ctrl16.description: Before an exam, the worst-case scenario plays out in the mind. The body reacts with tension, as if to a real threat.
ctrl16.why: The neocortex, through the imagined scenario, activated the limbic response.

ctrl17.title: Slipping
ctrl17.description: A sudden slip happens. The body instantly restores balance, and only then does fear set in.
ctrl17.why: The reptilian brain first provided stabilization; then the limbic system added the emotional response.

ctrl18.title: Panic and Concentration
ctrl18.description: A feeling of panic arises. Then attention is deliberately shifted to counting objects around to regain control.
ctrl18.why: The neocortex used a concentration technique to dampen the limbic system.

ctrl19.title: Unpleasant Letter
ctrl19.description: After receiving an unpleasant letter, tension in the body and a faster heartbeat arise.
ctrl19.why: The limbic system triggered the bodily response to emotional distress.

ctrl20.title: Impulse to Snap Back
ctrl20.description: A strong desire to reply sharply arises. There's a pause, then a more measured response is chosen.
ctrl20.why: The neocortex suppressed the limbic impulse and took control.
